newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait concerned over Russia-Iraq oil deal - report.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait concerned over Russia-Iraq oil deal - report.

text.p: Kuwait's Information Minister Sheikh Saud Nasser al-Sabah voiced concern over a Russian-Iraqi deal to develop an Iraqi oilfield, a newspaper reported on Monday.

"What we have heard lately about a Russian-Iraqi agreement to develop Iraqi oilfields...is a matter that causes concern," al-Rai al-Aam newspaper quoted Sheikh Saud as telling a lecture about the Gulf Arab state's media.
Iraq and Russia signed on Friday a contract to develop seven to eight billion barrels of reserves in southern Iraq's west Qurnah oilfield.
Russian Fuel and Energy Minister Pyotr Rodionov said the contract would be implemented regardless of the United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.

But Russian officials involved in the deal said on Monday that the accord will not involve any drilling, output or other work on the ground until U.N. sanctions were lifted. They said the sanctions will be fully observed.
The deal to develop the field, some 160 km (100 mile) away from Kuwait's border with Iraq, would be implemented over 23 years.
The curbs place a blanket ban on Iraqi exports and investments in the country. The U.N. has allowed Iraq to pump $2 billion worth of oil over six months on humanitarian grounds.
Rodionov put cost of constructing the project at $3.5 billion without saying how that amount would be paid and by whom.
